Albania.name: Albanian Energy Regulator Authority
Albania.notes: Regulator: Albanian Energy Regulator Authority (ERE)  "ERE is a public legal entity, independent from the energy industry interest and from government institutions. ERE is established on 1995 and operates based on Law no. 43/2015, of 30.04.2015 “For power sector” and Law no.102/2015 "For natural gas sector" (https://www.ere.gov.al/en/ere/what-is-ere)

Algeria.name: Electricity and Gas Regulatory Commission
Algeria.notes: Regulator: Electricity and Gas Regulatory Commission (CREG) "The main competencies and functions of CREG are: – Licencing – Demand Forecast/ Investment Planning – Remuneration of Operators and Tariffs – Access to Networks/ Markets – Quality Regulations/ Technical and Environmental Control – Consumer Protection" (https://erranet.org/member/creg-algeria/)

American Samoa.name: The Office of the Regulator is Samoa’s Regulator for the telecommunications, broadcasting, postal and electricity sectors.
American Samoa.notes: Regulator: The Office of the Regulator is Samoa’s Regulator for the telecommunications, broadcasting, postal and electricity sectors.

Angola.name: IRSEA
Angola.notes: Regulator: IRSEA (Instituto Regulador dos Serviços de Electricidade e Águas) established in 2016 (http://www.irsea.gov.ao/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Decreto-Presidencial-n%C2%BA-59-16-Estatuto-do-IRSEA.pdf) "We are the Regulatory Institute for Electricity Services and Water Supply and Waste Water Sanitation, an Institute for the economic or productive sector, a legal person governed by public law, created by Presidential Decree No. 59/16, of March 16, under the supervision of the Ministry da Energia e Águas, endowed with legal personality, administrative, financial and patrimonial autonomy." (http://www.irsea.gov.ao/irsea/)

Antigua and Barbuda.notes: No regulator. Antigua Public Utilities Authority (APUA) is the VIU and also has regulatory powers. Since this is not an independent entity, I am not considering it as a regulator. "The Antigua Public Utilities Authority is a tripartite government statutory agency set up under the Public Utilities Act No. 10 of 1973 (and subsequently as amended) to ensure that consumers receive the best possible value in Telecommunications (including mobile & internet), Electricity and Water services. Policy formulation and introduction of legislation as required to successfully fulfill APUA’s mission comes from the Minister with responsibility for Public Utilities, who is a member of the Cabinet of Antigua & Barbuda. The day-to-day operation of the organization is vested by the General Manager, who is assisted by a Management Team. Oversight is provided by the Board of Commissioners also appointed by Cabinet." (http://www.apua.ag/about/)

Argentina.name: The Energy Secretariat
Argentina.notes: Regulator: The Energy Secretariat (SENER) is responsible for policy setting, while the National Electricity Regulator (ENRE) is the independent entity within the Energy Secretariat responsible for applying the regulatory framework established by Law 26,046 of 1991.

Armenia.name: Public Services Regulatory Commission
Armenia.notes: Regulator: Public Services Regulatory Commission (PSRC) (https://www.psrc.am/) "It was established on April 3, 1997 by the decree of the President of the Republic of Armenia as the Energy Commission of the Republic of Armenia." (https://www.psrc.am/contents/page/history)

Aruba.notes: No regulator. "WEB Aruba became an independent company in January 1992. WEB Aruba and N.V. ELMAR were incorporated as separate companies into Utilities Aruba NV, a holding company with the Government of Aruba as the sole shareholder." (https://webaruba.com/company/organization)

Australia.name: Australian Energy Market Commission
Australia.notes: Regulator:  Australian Energy Market Commission (AEMC) was established in 2005.

Austria.name: Electricity-Control Commission
Austria.notes: Regulator: Electricity-Control Commission (ECC) created in 2001 as the regulator

Azerbaijan.name: "The Azerbaijan Energy Regulatory Agency
Azerbaijan.notes: Regulator: "The Azerbaijan Energy Regulatory Agency (AERA) regulates and inspects issues related to electricity, gas and heat supply. Established with the Presidential Decree №1750 by the 22nd of December 2017, the Agency operates as a public legal entity under the Ministry of Energy. After liquidation of two state bodies under the Ministry of Energy  as the State Energy Control Administration and the State Gas Control Administration of the Ministry of Energy,  the assets and liabilities of the abolished bodies were passed to the Agency. In April 2018, the Agency started its business operations. AERA consists of the Management Board, departments, divisions and units operating in the headquarters of the Agency, as well as via its branches located in the regions of Azerbaijan. " (https://regulator.gov.az/en/agentlik/haqqimizda)

Bahamas.name: Utilities Regulation & Competition Authority
Bahamas.notes: Regulator: Utilities Regulation & Competition Authority (https://www.urcabahamas.bs/) "The Utilities Regulation and Competition Authority (URCA) is the independent regulatory authority with responsibility for the Electronic Communications Sector (ECS) and the Electricity Sector (ES) in The Bahamas. The ECS comprises fixed and mobile telephone services, spectrum and numbering, broadcasting including pay television and Internet services. As regulator of the ES, URCA remit covers all persons who generate, transmit, distribute or supply electricity to from or within The Bahamas.

Bahrain.notes: Ministry of Electricity and Water Affair is in charge of the sector, there is no independent regulator

Bangladesh.name: Bangladesh Energy Regulatory Commission or BERC was established in 2003. It is a regulatory agency that regulates the gas, electricity and petroleum products in Bangladesh and is located in Dhaka. Its duties entail the management, operation and tariff determination of the electricity, gas and petroleum sectors. BERC also governs all matters related to licensing, and is mandated to promote competition and  conflict resolution within the sectors it governs. Bangladesh. http://www.berc.org.bd/
Bangladesh.notes: Regulator:  Bangladesh Energy Regulatory Commission or BERC was established in 2003. It is a regulatory agency that regulates the gas, electricity and petroleum products in Bangladesh and is located in Dhaka. Its duties entail the management, operation and tariff determination of the electricity, gas and petroleum sectors. BERC also governs all matters related to licensing, and is mandated to promote competition and  conflict resolution within the sectors it governs. Bangladesh. http://www.berc.org.bd/

Barbados.notes: Ministry of Energy regulates the sector, there is no independent regulator.

Belarus.notes: In terms of energy sector regulation, there is no single independent body acting as an energy regulatory authority. Instead, residential energy tariffs are regulated by the Council of Ministers and approved by the president, while electricity and heat tariffs for all non-residential sectors, including tariffs for electricity and heat sales to industry and for electricity sale by independent power producers (IPPs), are regulated by the Ministry of Anti-Monopoly Regulation and Trade (MART).

Belgium.name: "Regulatory responsibility over the Belgian electricity market is divided between the federal regulator, the Commission for Electricity and Gas Regulation
Belgium.notes: Regulator: "Regulatory responsibility over the Belgian electricity market is divided between the federal regulator, the Commission for Electricity and Gas Regulation (CREG), and the three regional regulators: the VREG in Flanders, the CWaPE in Wallonia and the Brugel in the Brussels-Capital Region. The regulatory authorities are independent, both from market players and from policy makers. The CREG is responsible for the electricity transmission system, including approval of transmission tariffs, and also advises the federal government on gas and electricity markets. The VREG, CWaPE and Brugel approve distribution tariffs and regulate electricity distribution and compliance with regional public service obligations. They also advise each regional government on the operation of the gas and electricity markets. The regional regulators monitor retail market competition in their respective regions, while the CREG monitors wholesale market competition" (https://iea.blob.core.windows.net/assets/638cb377-ca57-4c16-847d-ea4d96218d35/Belgium2022_EnergyPolicyReview.pdf) (https://www.ampliz.com/company/creg-commission-for-electricity-and-gas-regulation-belgium/98129102)

Belize.name: The Ministry of Public Utilities, Energy and Logistics
Belize.notes: Regulator: The Ministry of Public Utilities, Energy and Logistics (MoPUEL) is responsible for the energy sector. The Public Utilities Commission (PUC) regulates all entities involved in the generation and supply of electricity and oversees rates and regulation. "The Belize Public Utilities Commission (PUC) regulates the water, electricity, and telecommunication sectors in Belize ensuring that these services are accessible, of high quality, and affordable for consumers and that the sectors are viable and sustainable." "The Public Utilities Commission was established in 2001 incorporating the traditional regulatory bodies, the Office of Electricity Supply and the Office of Telecommunications to regulate the electricity, water, and telecommunications sectors in Belize. These sectors are essential commodities for any economy therefore the work of the PUC is critical to Belize’s economy. The PUC’s mandate is legally obliged by the Public Utilities Commission Substantive Act Chapter 223 Revised Edition 2020."  (https://www.puc.bz/)

Benin.name: Autorité de Régulation de l'Électricité du Bénin:Electricity Regulatory Authority is an independent administrative authority, endowed with legal personality and financial autonomy, placed under the authority of the President of the Republic of Benin. It ensures compliance with legislative and regulatory texts by the various public and private players involved in the electricity sector. It is responsible for protecting the interests of public or private operators and consumers and for guaranteeing the continuity and quality of service, the financial balance of the sector and its harmonious development.
Benin.notes: Regulator: Autorité de Régulation de l'Électricité du Bénin:Electricity Regulatory Authority is an independent administrative authority, endowed with legal personality and financial autonomy, placed under the authority of the President of the Republic of Benin. It ensures compliance with legislative and regulatory texts by the various public and private players involved in the electricity sector. It is responsible for protecting the interests of public or private operators and consumers and for guaranteeing the continuity and quality of service, the financial balance of the sector and its harmonious development. (https://are.bj/) From what I understood it was established in 2015.

Bermuda.name: "The RA is an independent regulator established under the Regulatory Authority Act 2011. The RA has the power to supervise, monitor and regulate any regulated industry sector in accordance with the Regulatory Authority Act 2011, sectoral legislation and any regulations or policies made by the Minister. The RA currently regulates the Electronic Communications, Electricity and Submarine Communication Cables sectors. Within its scope, the RA may make administrative determinations and has the power to issue adjudicative decisions and orders as appropriate."
Bermuda.notes: Regulator: "The RA is an independent regulator established under the Regulatory Authority Act 2011. The RA has the power to supervise, monitor and regulate any regulated industry sector in accordance with the Regulatory Authority Act 2011, sectoral legislation and any regulations or policies made by the Minister. The RA currently regulates the Electronic Communications, Electricity and Submarine Communication Cables sectors. Within its scope, the RA may make administrative determinations and has the power to issue adjudicative decisions and orders as appropriate." (https://www.ra.bm/ )

Bhutan.name: "The Electricity Act 2001 restructured the country’s electricity sector. Bhutan Electricity Authority was established as the regulatory body"
Bhutan.notes: Regulator: "The Electricity Act 2001 restructured the country’s electricity sector. Bhutan Electricity Authority was established as the regulatory body" (https://www.drukgreen.bt/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Corporate-Profile-.pdf)

Bolivia.name: 1994 regulation create regulator: The Superintendency of Electricity, an autonomous agency with an independent budget, is in charge of supervising compliance with sector regulation and of approving tariffs. In 1994 create energy regulator "Superintendent of Electricity has oversight responsibility for the electricity sector."
Bolivia.notes: Regulator: 1994 regulation create regulator: The Superintendency of Electricity, an autonomous agency with an independent budget, is in charge of supervising compliance with sector regulation and of approving tariffs. In 1994 create energy regulator "Superintendent of Electricity has oversight responsibility for the electricity sector." (https://www.osti.gov/servlets/purl/821117) Authority of Fiscalisation and Social Control of Electricity (AE). The AE regulates activities carried out by operators providing electricity services in Bolivia, guaranteeing the interests and rights of consumers and users. CNDC is the regulator "The establishment of the Superintendence of Electricity, which began its activity in January 1996;" (https://www.cndc.bo/empresa/conformacion.php)

Bosnia and Herzegovina.name: In Federal BiH Federal Electricity Regulatory Comission is in charge of the electricity supply; in Republika Srpska Regulatory Commission for Energy Sprpska
Bosnia and Herzegovina.notes: Regulator: In Federal BiH Federal Electricity Regulatory Comission is in charge of the electricity supply; in Republika Srpska Regulatory Commission for Energy Sprpska (RERS) is responsible. In Brcko District state level regulatory authority SERC is repsonsible. Under the Law on Electricity in Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina of 2013, the Federal Ministry of Energy, Mining and Industry and the Federal Regulatory Commission for Energy (FERK) are the key institutions responsible for the functioning of the electricity sector in Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Likewise, under the Law on Electricity in the Republic of Srpska of 2008 and the Energy Law in Republika Srpska of 2009, the two key institutions responsible for legal and regulatory framework in electricity sector of Republika Srpska are the Ministry of Industry, Energy and Mining and the Regulatory Commission for Energy of Republika Srpska (RERS).

Botswana.name: Botswana Energy Regulatory Authority is the energy regulator and a government parastatal of the Botswana government. The parastatal was founded after the Botswana Energy Regulatory Act was put in place in 2016 and started its operations on the 1st September, 2017.
Botswana.notes: Regulator: Botswana Energy Regulatory Authority is the energy regulator and a government parastatal of the Botswana government. The parastatal was founded after the Botswana Energy Regulatory Act was put in place in 2016 and started its operations on the 1st September, 2017. (https://www.bera.co.bw/)

Brazil.name: ANEEL – Brazilian Electricity Regulatory Agency: It is the regulator and oversight of the sector that has been following the policies and guidelines of the Federal Government. The agency is responsible for auctioning the granting of generation and transmission, on behalf of the MME. The National Electric Power Agency
Brazil.notes: Regulator: ANEEL – Brazilian Electricity Regulatory Agency: It is the regulator and oversight of the sector that has been following the policies and guidelines of the Federal Government. The agency is responsible for auctioning the granting of generation and transmission, on behalf of the MME. The National Electric Power Agency (ANEEL) is a special autarchy that regulates the electric power market in Brazil. It was created in 1996, amid efforts to decentralise executive powers in Brazil and generate independence, by Federal Law No. 9,427/1996, which further provides for the concession regime for the electric power system.

British Virgin Islands.notes: There is no independent regulator currently.

Brunei.notes: Electricity sector in Brunei is regulated by the Department of Electrical Services (DES; Malay: Jabatan Perkhidmatan Elektrik) under the Ministry of Energy. (http://www.des.gov.bn/SitePages/about.aspx#brief-history-section)

Bulgaria.name: The functions of an independent regulator of the energy and water markets are served by the SEWRC. It was established in 1999 as the energy regulator but from the beginning of 2005 the water regulation was included in its functions.
Bulgaria.notes: Regulator: The functions of an independent regulator of the energy and water markets are served by the SEWRC. It was established in 1999 as the energy regulator but from the beginning of 2005 the water regulation was included in its functions.

Burkina Faso.name: Electricity Regulatory Authority
Burkina Faso.notes: Regulator: Electricity Regulatory Authority (ARSE) "The Energy Sector Regulatory Authority (ARSE) is an independent administrative authority with legal personality and financial and management autonomy. It ensures the regulation, control and monitoring of the activities of operators and operators in the energy sector. ARSE has its headquarters in Ouagadougou and can create decentralized structures if necessary." (Among the major institutional changes introduced by Law No. 027-2007 of November 20, 2007 is the creation of the Electricity Sub-sector Regulatory Authority (ARSE) having the status of an independent administrative authority attached to the Prime Ministry. and enjoying financial autonomy." (https://www.arse.bf/spip.php?article1)

Burundi.name: The Authority for Regulation of Water and Energy Sectors
Burundi.notes: Regulator: The Authority for Regulation of Water and Energy Sectors (French: Autorité de Régulation des secteurs de l'Eau potable et de l’Energie (AREEN)) is an independent regulatory authority of Burundi mandated to provide for technical and economic regulation of electricity and water utilities.

Cape Verde.name: Agência Reguladora Multissetorial da Economia
Cape Verde.notes: Regulator: Agência Reguladora Multissetorial da Economia (ARME), a multi-sector regulatory authority, is tasked with economic and technical regulation of the electricity sector. Multisectoral Regulatory Agency for the Economy, created under Decree-Law No. 50/2018, of 20 September and as an administrative and independent authority, performs the administrative activity of technical and economic regulation of the communications, energy, water and public urban and interurban passenger transport.

Cambodia.name: The Electricity Authority of Cambodia
Cambodia.notes: Regulator: The Electricity Authority of Cambodia (EAC) was created under the Electricity Law of 2001 and is a legal public entity granted the right by the Royal Government to be an autonomous agency tasked with regulating the power sector. "It is responsible for issuing rules, regulations, and procedures, and for monitoring, guiding, and coordinating operators in the power sector, as well as consumers, including requiring them to follow the policy, guidelines, and technical standards issued by the MME" (https://media.vdb-loi.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Cambodia-Power-Update-April-2018.pdf)

Cameroon.name: "The Electricity Sector Regulatory Agency
Cameroon.notes: Regulator: "The Electricity Sector Regulatory Agency (ARSEL) was created by Law N” 98/022 of 24th December, 1998 substituted by Law N°2011/022 of i4th December, 2011, to regulate the electricity sector In Cameroon. It has the status of a Public Administrative Institution Within the framework of Law N° 99/016 of 22nd December. 1999, on the general statute of public enterprises and enterprises of the public and para-public sectors." (https://erranet.org/member/arsel-cameroon/)

Canada.name: New regulator formed in 2019 replacing National Energy Board
Canada.notes: Regulator: New regulator formed in 2019 replacing National Energy Board (NEB). NEB was formed in 1959 so I am recording 1959 as the year regulatory body was formed for the energy sector.

Cayman Islands.name: Currently OfReg is the Cayman Islands’ independent economic multi-sector regulator covering several sectors including energy. It was established in 2017 by consolidating 3 regulatory agencies including the Electricity Regulatory Authority
Cayman Islands.notes: Regulator: Currently OfReg is the Cayman Islands’ independent economic multi-sector regulator covering several sectors including energy. It was established in 2017 by consolidating 3 regulatory agencies including the Electricity Regulatory Authority (ERA) which was established by law in 2010 (see https://www.ofreg.ky/viewPDF/documents/energy/2021-12-15-09-42-15-Electricity-Regulatory-Authority-Law-2010-Revision.pdf). I am counting this 2010 authority as the first regulator.

Central African Republic.notes: There is no independent energy regulator. The Ministry of Mining, Energy and Hydraulics is in charge of the energy sector. (https://wedocs.unep.org/bitstream/handle/20.500.11822/20497/Energy_profile_CentralAfricanRep.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y#:~:text=The%20Ministry%20of%20Mining%2C%20Energy,charge%20of%20the%20energy%20sector.)

Chad.name: l'Autorité de Régulation du Secteur de l'Energie Électrique
Chad.notes: Regulator: l'Autorité de Régulation du Secteur de l'Energie Électrique (ARSE): "Chad has set up an Electricity Sector Regulatory Authority (ARSE). The law bearing its birth was voted on December 21, 2018 by the deputies within the framework of the law relating to the electric energy sector in Chad." (https://tchadinfos.com/energie-une-autorite-de-regulation-du-secteur-de-lenergie-electrique-est-creee/)  I could not find the regulator's website but seems to be operational. I found local news articles referencing it since 2020.

Channel Islands.name: Guernsey Competition and Regulatory Authorities
Channel Islands.notes: Regulator: Guernsey Competition and Regulatory Authorities (GCRA) is in charge of the sector.

Chile.name: National Energy Commission
Chile.notes: Regulator: National Energy Commission (CNE, Comisión Nacional de Energía) was created in 1978, it was a specialized instiution with regulatory and advisory roels on energy issues. CNE is in charge of controlling prices in the regulated segment of the electricity market. It also responsible for implementing the energy efficiency and renewable policies.

China.name: State Electricity Regulatory Commission
China.notes: Regulator: State Electricity Regulatory Commission (SERC) was set up in October 2002.

Colombia.name: CREG—Regulatory Commission for Electricity and Gas was established in 1994.
Colombia.notes: Regulator: CREG—Regulatory Commission for Electricity and Gas was established in 1994.

Comoros.notes: Currently there is no energy regulator in Comoros but there are plans to establish one. "Comoros is set to establish an autonomous energy regulator with support from the project on Enhancement of a Sustainable Regional Energy Market (ESREM) in the Eastern Africa, Southern Africa, and Indian Ocean (EA-SA-IO) Region.  Currently, the island country has no active energy regulator." (https://www.comesa.int/comoros-to-have-a-national-energy-regulation-board/)

Democratic Republic of the Congo.notes: Ministry of Mines, Energy and Hydrocarbons is in charge of the sector, there is no regulator present.

Congo.notes: There is no independent regulator currently.

Cook Islands.notes: There doesn't appear to be an independent regulatory body, the sector seems to be under the purview of ministry of economy. ADB in 2021 launched a TA to support regulatory capacity in Pacific Islands "Pacific DMCs have recognized the importance of regulation and many of them have established dedicated national regulatory bodies to perform regulatory functions. Other DMCs operate the regulatory framework through smaller units spread throughout several agencies or ministries, resulting in less efficient and effective reforms" (https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-documents/49450/49450-035-tar-en.pdf)

Costa Rica.notes: Water Office of the Environmental and Energy Ministry (MINAE) seems to be in charge of the sector, there is no separate regulatory authority.

Ivory Coast.name: The Côte d’Ivoire Electricity sector Regulation National Authority
Ivory Coast.notes: Regulator: The Côte d’Ivoire Electricity sector Regulation National Authority (ANARE-CI): the National Regulatory Agency, which monitors compliance with regulations and conventions in force, settles disputes, protects consumer interests, and advises and assists the Ivoirian government.

Croatia.name: Croatian Energy Regulatory Agency
Croatia.notes: Regulator: Croatian Energy Regulatory Agency (HERA) was established in 2004.

Cuba.notes: There is no independent regulator currently.

Curaçao.notes: There is no independent regulator currently.

Cyprus.name: The gas and power sectors share the same regulator in Cyprus
Cyprus.notes: Regulator: The gas and power sectors share the same regulator in Cyprus (CERA)."The Cyprus Energy Regulatory Authority (CERA) has been established in 2003 in accordance with the European Union directives. According to the responsibilities and the authorization given by the law, it is the National Independent Regulatory Authority for Energy which is able, to oversee and regulate the market for the electricity and gas, ensure effective and fair competition, protect the interest of the consumers, ensure safety, quality, competence, continuity and reliability in the energy supply, as well as encouraging the use of RES." (https://www.cera.org.cy/en-gb/home)

Czech Republic.name: "ERO was established in 2001 by the Energy Act, which also sets out its competences."
Czech Republic.notes: Regulator: "ERO was established in 2001 by the Energy Act, which also sets out its competences." (https://www.eru.cz/en/about-ero)

Denmark.name: Since 1976 there is an energy agency whithin the ministry of energy. A separate independent regulator for utilities was established in 2018.
Denmark.notes: Regulator: Since 1976 there is an energy agency whithin the ministry of energy. A separate independent regulator for utilities was established in 2018.

Djibouti.notes: There is no independent regulator currently.

Dominica.name: "Prior to the establishment of the Independent Regulatory Commission
Dominica.notes: Regulator:  "Prior to the establishment of the Independent Regulatory Commission (IRC) in 2006, the availability of electricity power in Dominica was a total mess. The Dominica Electric Power Company (DOMLEC), a privately-owned power company, provided electricity to consumers....The IRC was established under the Electricity Supply Act which was passed into law in October 2006. The commission was set up according to the dictates of the National Electric Power Policy which is aimed at a complete overhaul of electricity services in Dominica." (https://www.ircdominica.org/about-us/establishment-irc/)

Dominican Republic.name: The National Energy Commission
Dominican Republic.notes: Regulator: The National Energy Commission (CNE), an institution attached to the Ministry of Energy and Mines, is a public and decentralized body, with its own assets, created in accordance with article 7 of the General Electricity Law No. 125-01, in charge of managing operational energy policies and monitoring compliance with Law No. 57-07, on Incentives for the Development of Renewable Energy Sources and their Special Regimes. The 2001 Law and its supporting regulations from 2002 included the creation of an autonomous regulatory agency, the Electricity Superintendence (SIE). It also created the National Energy Commission (CNE) and a wholesale market under responsibility of a Coordinating Agency

Ecuador.name: "Ecuadorian government passed the Act Establishing the Public Electric Power Service in 2015, which outlined the regulation of the Ecuadorian power sector. Under this act, CONELEC was rebranded as the Agencia de Regulación y Control de Electricidad
Ecuador.notes: Regulator: "Ecuadorian government passed the Act Establishing the Public Electric Power Service in 2015, which outlined the regulation of the Ecuadorian power sector. Under this act, CONELEC was rebranded as the Agencia de Regulación y Control de Electricidad (ARCONEL)." (https://www.eia.gov/international/analysis/country/ECU/background)

Egypt.name: "Despite the issuance of a presidential decree to institute a regulator as early as 1997, no progress was made. A second such decree was issued in 2000. Thereafter, a board of directors was formed and a managing director appointed in May 2001. Staffing of the Egyptian Electric Utility and Consumer Protection Regulatory Agency
Egypt.notes: Regulator: "Despite the issuance of a presidential decree to institute a regulator as early as 1997, no progress was made. A second such decree was issued in 2000. Thereafter, a board of directors was formed and a managing director appointed in May 2001. Staffing of the Egyptian Electric Utility and Consumer Protection Regulatory Agency (ERA), with a grant from USAID, began in January 2002. Thus, the regulator came into force only after the IPP PPAs had been concluded and changes to EEA/EEHC had taken place as well." (https://fsi-live.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/Egypt_IPP_Experience_.pdf)

El Salvador.name: The General Superintendency of Electricity and Telecommunications
El Salvador.notes: Regulator: The General Superintendency of Electricity and Telecommunications (SIGET), is an autonomous non-profit public service institution, appointed to apply the norms contained in electricity and telecommunications international treaties, that have been in force in El Salvador since 1997." (https://gsacom.com/associate/siget-el-salvador/)

Equatorial Guinea.notes: Ministry of Mines, Industry, and Energy is in charge of the sector there is no independent regulator

Eritrea.name: Electricity Regulatory Committee was established within the Ministry of Energy in 2004, it is envisaged to become and independent regulator. As I understand it has not yet become a regulator. "The Electricity Regulatory Committee
Eritrea.notes: Regulator: Electricity Regulatory Committee was established within the Ministry of Energy in 2004, it is envisaged to become and independent regulator. As I understand it has not yet become a regulator. "The Electricity Regulatory Committee (ERC) has been established by Proclamation No. 141/2004 in order to become an independent regulator. At the moment ERC operates under the mandate of the Department of Energy in the Ministry of Energy and Mines. Energy will be a focal area in the 11th EDF." "Electricity Regulatory Committee (ERC) currently not an independent regulatory body but is established under the mandate of the Department of Energy in the Ministry of Energy and Mines. The establishing law foresees that ERC will become an independent regulator." (https://europa.eu/capacity4dev/file/30316/download?token=SjZauJGg#:~:text=The%20Electricity%20Regulatory%20Committee%20(ERC,Ministry%20of%20Energy%20and%20Mines.&text=Energy%20will%20be%20a%20focal%20area%20in%20the%2011th%20EDF.)

Estonia.name: Estonian Competition Authority
Estonia.notes: Regulator: Estonian Competition Authority (ECA)  regulates the sector: "The Estonian Competition Authority exercises state supervision in the fields of competition, electricity, natural gas, district heating, postal services, public water supply and sewerage, railways, and ports. In addition, the Authority resolves disputes and complaints related to airport and port charges and monitors unfair commercial practices. The Authority is in the area of government of the Ministry of Justice." (https://one.oecd.org/document/DAF/COMP/AR(2022)10/en/pdf)  I wasn't able to find the exact date it was established but seems to be around 1999 (https://ec.europa.eu/competition/sectors/media/documents/estonia.pdf)

Eswatini.name: Eswatini Energy Regulatory Authority
Eswatini.notes: Regulator: Eswatini Energy Regulatory Authority (ESERA): The Eswatini Energy Regulatory Authority, ESERA, is a category A public enterprise which was established in terms of the Energy Act of 2007. The Authority is mandated to: Administer the Electricity Act, 2007 (Act No.3 of 2007), with the primary and core responsibilities of exercising control over the electricity supply industry (ESI) and ensuring the security of supply of electricity through the issuance of licences and the regulation of electricity tariffs and quality of supply and services. Administer the Petroleum Act of 2020, through the licencing and inspection of downstream activities.

Ethiopia.name: The EEA is the key regulator of the energy sector in Ethiopia and is accountable to MoWIE.The EEA has a Director General and the Energy Board
Ethiopia.notes: Regulator: The EEA is the key regulator of the energy sector in Ethiopia and is accountable to MoWIE.The EEA has a Director General and the Energy Board (a high-level policy body chaired by the State Minister of Water, Energy and Irrigation). The main objectives of the EEA are to:

Faroe Islands.notes: There is no independent regulator currently.

Fiji.name: Electricity is regulated by the Fijian Competition and Consumer Commission "Fijian Competition and Consumer Commission
Fiji.notes: Regulator: Electricity is regulated by the Fijian Competition and Consumer Commission "Fijian Competition and Consumer Commission (FCCC) is an independent statutory body established under section 7 of the Fijian Competition and Consumer Commission Act 2010. FCCC promotes effective competition and an informed market, encourages fair trade in markets and protects customers and businesses from restrictive practices. FCCC also controls and regulates prices of regulated industries and other markets where competition is lessened or limited, such as (but not limited to), electricity, telecommunications, posts, maritime and airport sectors. Our primary responsibility is to ensure compliance of consumer protection laws contained in Fijian Competition and Consumer Commission Act 2010." (https://fccc.gov.fj/about-fccc-2/)

Finland.name: The Energy Agency
Finland.notes: Regulator: The Energy Agency ( Swedish: Energimyndigheten ) is an expert agency belonging to the Ministry of Labor and the Economy . It was initially called Sähkömarkkinakeskus (SMK) when created in 1995 and before the latest name change Energy Market Agency (EMV).The tasks of the Energy Agency include monitoring the pricing of the electricity transmission network and the natural gas market and maintaining Finland's national emissions trading register . The agency also provides information on the price of electricity to consumers to support tendering for electricity suppliers. In addition, the Energy Agency supervises the realization of the guarantee of origin of electricity, i.e. that the energy corresponding to the amount of energy sold to consumers by the energy company as wind electricity, for example, has been produced by wind power. The Energy Agency also administers the renewable energy feed-in tariffs that entered into force in 2011 . (https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energiavirasto)

France.name: "The CRE, an independent regulatory authority is responsible for monitoring access to electricity and gas transmission and distribution networks. Generally speaking, the CRE has to ensure that electricity and gas systems are operated and developed in a non-discriminatory manner. Several other functions have been conferred to it including tariffs, tender processes for renewable generation and regulating the access of EDF’s competitors to EDF’s nuclear energy "
France.notes: Regulator: "The CRE, an independent regulatory authority is responsible for monitoring access to electricity and gas transmission and distribution networks. Generally speaking, the CRE has to ensure that electricity and gas systems are operated and developed in a non-discriminatory manner. Several other functions have been conferred to it including tariffs, tender processes for renewable generation and regulating the access of EDF’s competitors to EDF’s nuclear energy " (https://cms.law/en/int/expert-guides/cms-expert-guide-to-electricity/france)

French Guiana.name: French Energy Regulation Commission
French Guiana.notes: Regulator:  French Energy Regulation Commission (CRE) regulates the electricity sector as this is an overseas territory.

French Polynesia.notes: There is no independent regulator currently.

Gabon.name: Agence de Régulation du Secteur de l’Eau Potable et de l’Energie Electrique or ARSEE formed in 2018. I was not able to find their website but they do have a facebook page
Gabon.notes: Regulator:  Agence de Régulation du Secteur de l’Eau Potable et de l’Energie Electrique or ARSEE formed in 2018. I was not able to find their website but they do have a facebook page (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authority_for_Regulation_of_Water_and_Energy_Sectors)

Gambia.name: "PURA was initially created by The Gambia Public Utilities Regulatory Authority Act, 2001
Gambia.notes: Regulator:  "PURA was initially created by The Gambia Public Utilities Regulatory Authority Act, 2001 (the “PURA Act”) as an independent agency with the mandate to regulate certain “regulated public services”, which are defined in section 2(1) of the act as meaning “a communication service, a transport service, an energy service or a water service provided directly or indirectly to the public or to any section of the public”.

Georgia.name: "Georgian National Energy and Water Supply Regulatory Commission
Georgia.notes: Regulator: "Georgian National Energy and Water Supply Regulatory Commission (GNERC) celebrated its 16-year anniversary in 2013. The Commission has been regulating the electricity sphere since 1997, taking over the natural gas sector regulation in 1999 and water supply sector regulation in 2007 (as a result of legal changes). Initially, the Commission was established under the Ministry of Economy in August,1996 and its main function was to calculate wholesale and retail electricity tariffs." (https://gnerc.org/en/commission/commission-history/history)

Germany.name: The Energy Act assigned the task of regulating Germany's electricity and gas markets to the Bundesnetzagentur. The purpose of regulation is to establish fair and effective competition in the supply of electricity and gas. The responsibilities of the Bundesnetzagentur therefore include ensuring non-discriminatory third-party access to networks and policing the use-of-system charges levied by market players. "Our authority was founded in 1998 as part of the process of liberalising the postal and telecommunications markets. Our task was to ensure fair and non-discriminatory competition for all market participants. Our success and our expertise in regulation led to the energy and rail sectors also being placed under our responsibility."
Germany.notes: Regulator: The Energy Act assigned the task of regulating Germany's electricity and gas markets to the Bundesnetzagentur. The purpose of regulation is to establish fair and effective competition in the supply of electricity and gas.
